messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba help please
messages.msgSnippet: ... Honestly, I wouldn t hang your hat on it being anything great, especially from Government officials in 1921!!  I ve seen a tanto talked up because it was
messages.messageBody:
> it was a gift from two japanese goverment officials
> back in 1921,,,,,,so thats why i want to find out more....

Honestly, I wouldn't hang your hat on it being anything great, especially
from Government officials in 1921!! I've seen a tanto "talked up" because
it was a gift from the Emperor. Maybe, maybe not, but it had red lacquer in
the grooves (yuck) and katana fuchigashira that looked really out of place.
Send your tsuba to Shinsa in Japan and all will be revealed...

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba help please
messages.msgSnippet: hi yes was a good find,,but asking more established collectors if they know more about it.was willing to exchange for a katana blade on my local forum but they
messages.messageBody:
hi
yes was a good find,,but asking more established collectors if they know
more about it.was willing to exchange for a katana blade on my local forum but
they were no takers,it was there i was told if i wanted to sell then the tops
for it if shoami will be $1500 or nara $2500,it looks nara,pics do not do it
justice,and it was a gift from two japanese goverment officials back in
1921,,,,,,so thats why i want to find out more....

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba help please
messages.msgSnippet: So late it has never been mounted on a sword??  A snippet of older knowledge I carry with me has it that there are immensely greater numbers of tsuba made than
messages.messageBody:
So late it has never been mounted on a sword?? A snippet of older knowledge
I carry with me has it that there are immensely greater numbers of tsuba
made than there were ever blades to mount them on... This would seem to be
one?

Barry Thomas.


> can anyone tell me more about this aizu shoami/nara tusba.....circa
> 1850,,,please read previous posts

IMHO, it is Nara rather than Aizu Shoami. It lacks the common
tagane mei usually seen on many Aizu Shoami. Nice tsuba, as you
said I would suspect late Edo period.

Rich S
